questions.text: In what ways does the opening of the novel set the narrative in motion?

introduction: Discussion of a novel’s ‘opening’ is not restricted to the first page or first chapter, but to all early developments in the book and the way these relate to what follows.

points: The novel opens by plunging into an account of life at Gateshead Hall.
Jane establishes herself as controlling the narrative of her life.
Establishes credentials as fictional autobiography and bildungsroman.
Red Room episode anticipates further Gothic writing later in the story.
Jane’s tone suggests she is now a balanced, happily married lady looking back.
Jane’s insights into the dysfunctional family of the Reeds.
Confronts and morally overcomes Mrs Reed at age ten showing rectitude and feistiness.
Lowood sequence sharpened with personal reminiscence of the Brontë sisters’ time at Cowan Bridge.
Contrast between Jane’s independent spirit and the non-judgmental pacifism of Helen Burns.
context: Classic Victorian novels feature sections devoted to the childhood of the protagonist.
Spartan descriptions of Lowood contrast with pointless opulence at Gateshead Hall.
Jane as a ‘governess’, looking forward to a ‘new servitude’.
Brontë family interest in the doctrine of ‘universal salvation’ through Helen Burns.

points: Masterpiece of compression; Nick Carraway established as the filter/narrator at once.
Nick is fresh from World War One and looking to be ‘something in the City’.
Restrained style of opening chapters except for the description of Dr T.J. Eckleburg.
Gatsby as an ‘absent presence’, previewed by Nick as always in the forefront of his mind.
Gatsby is likely to be more socially mobile and impactful than other characters.
Lush inventive style exemplified by ambitious metaphors (e.g., New York trees).
context: Characters established as mid-Westerners attracted to New York/Long Island Sound.
Daisy, Tom, Nick and Jordan linked to the plutocracy and ‘old money’.
Wilson garage in the Valley of Ashes extends the social range.
Characters described as ‘morally footloose’ versus Gatsby’s ‘unbroken stream of successful gestures’.

points: Teasingly simple style requires ‘delayed decoding’ from the reader.
Pre-colonial world of the Igbo tribe restricted to ‘nine villages’.
Okonkwo’s prowess stems from martial deeds, making him a celebrity at eighteen.
Prose dominated by simple declarative writing, avoiding the abstract register.
Okonkwo established as insecure in his ‘achievement’, which can make him brutal.
Ikemefuma introduced early as an object of that brutality.
context: Artfully suggests isolated tribal life before Missionaries/colonists.
Prowess derived from local warfare; distinction between ‘just’ and ‘unjust’ wars is ignored.
Sporting contests (wrestling) and belief in curses/locusts/blood sacrifice.
The Oracle of the Hills and Caves possesses ultimate spiritual authority.

points: Opening section ‘Paradise, Pickles and Preserves’ shows enchanted existence of twins Estha and Rahel.
Lush, metaphorical prose reminiscent of Romantic accounts of childhood (e.g., Laurie Lee).
Drowning of Sophie Mol introduced early with the shadow of modern Indian culture.
Narrative serendipity and post-modern writing; the story has ‘no secrets’.
Unclear ‘contract’ with the reader at the start.
context: Novel shaped by the entrenched caste system despite independence.
Characters as former ‘untouchables’ converted to Christianity.
Estha and Rahel falling foul of ‘love laws’.
Chaotic plot delivery represents an attempt to overthrow the rigid fatalism of Indian culture.

points: Establishment of apprentice novelist Briony Tallis’s adolescent inner life.
Briony’s struggle to get Lola and the twins to participate in her play.
Language simulates the awkward pretension of very young writers.
Exposition misconstrues a ‘sexual misadventure’ in a Country House novel atmosphere.
Prose weaving a sunlit ‘geometry of light’ reminiscent of Forster/Woolf.
Broken Meissen vase recalls Henry James’ The Golden Bowl.
Focus on a novelist writing a novel points up the distance between art and life.
context: Explores apparent luxury of upper-class life in inter-war years.
Hints of impending war (‘Mr Hitler needs to pipe down’).
Class system dynamics: Marshalls as rich proprietors; Robbie as a scholarship boy.
Briony’s literary penance for her childhood misunderstandings.

points: Begins with the birth of Gogol in a high-tech hospital in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Mother Ashima forced to swap ‘Murshidabad sari’ for hospital gown.
Ashoke mulls over Russian literature and Gogol’s ‘The Overcoat’.
Sequence provides early explanation of the novel’s title.
Bengali customs lie cheek-by-jowl with New England culture (e.g., Mother Goose haircut).
Slickly accessible style reminiscent of short stories in The New Yorker.
context: Setting in the genteel university town of Cambridge.
Consumer lifestyle of the sixties/seventies vs. obligations of Bengali culture.
Bengali words (daknam, bhalonam) left untranslated showing incomplete assimilation.
Slogans of the permissive society (e.g., ‘QUESTION AUTHORITY!’).

questions.marker_instruction: A higher level response (levels 4 to 6) will: Explore the ways the writer establishes key features of the text; Use vocabulary, terminology and narrative concepts appropriately; Show an understanding of the literary and generic context. A lower level response (level 1 – 3) will: Identify and list some ways; Use some appropriate vocabulary; Show limited understanding of the literary and generic context.

questions.text: In what ways does the writer of your text use symbols and motifs?

introduction: Candidates should range across the text to explore how symbols and motifs are used and the function they play in the novel as a whole.

points: Motif of the ‘fire of passion’ (Jane’s feelings, lightning on oak tree, Bertha as Firestarter, purgatorial flame).
Metaphors of imprisonment and repression (Bertha’s attic).
Spartan motifs at Lowood (forced haircuts, black pillar Brocklehurst).
Gothic implications of the Red Room and shadows at Thornfield.
Jane’s Romantic imagery in her pictures (Arctic wastes).
context: Symbolism of a pre-feminist novel: ‘fire’ as female passion and Bertha’s wild energy.
Gothic tropes viewed as ‘female Gothic’ (Bluebeard’s castle).
Rivals viewed as ‘flock of white plumy birds’ feeding off the patriarchy.

points: Green light at the end of Daisy’s dock as a symbol of hopes/American Dream.
Minatory symbols: eyes of Dr T.J. Eckleburg and the Valley of Ashes.
Symbols of fatal leisure (swimming-pool).
Overheated/overwrought symbolism generated by summer weather and setting.
Languid ominousness.
context: Destructive motor-cars and Wilson’s garage linked to post-WWI prosperity.
Motifs of conspicuous consumption (mansion, shirt, parties) suggest a bubble.
Eyes of T.J. Eckleburg as the durability of advertising/the eyes of God.

points: Avoids imagery where possible to distance from European novels about Africa.
Focuses on symbols physically embedded in text like ‘Roaring Flame’ (Okonkwo).
Beast fables (Tortoise and Cat) assume symbolic value.
Cultural symbols: masks covering elders playing resurrected ancestors.
Locusts as an uncomfortable prelude to the killing of Ikemefuna.
context: Symbols of language: English as an uncomfortable language for the colonial story.
The ‘poetry of the new religion’ (Christianity) vs. British administrative abstractions.
Hemingway-like directness without imagery.

points: Power of symbols on childhood experience.
The History House as a cultural crossroads and scene of dark adventures.
Grandiose landscape descriptions: toxic river and skull-like bed.
Pappachi’s moth as a symbol of unrecognized achievement and injustice.
Rahul’s watch, frozen at ten to two, symbolizes time vs. timelessness.
context: Paradise Pickles and Preserves ‘preserves’ cultural uses of the Raj.
Disruption by Communist party activities.

points: Uncle Clem’s Vase as a symbol of the past/heirloom, echoing Henry James.
Fountain and Temple as a theatrical, symbolic setting for Briony’s ‘crime’.
Amo Bars (Paul Marshall) as a motif of convenience and sexual offense.
Severed leg in the tree as a shock-value symbol in Dunkirk.
Dunkirk as a symbol of miraculous escape vs. historical facts beyond control.
context: Great house and controlled leisure of inter-war years.
Unseen mantraps of class.
Fixtures of Tallis home as semi-contrived cultural solidity (dead neo-classicism).

points: Gogol’s name as a series of rites of passage and tight chronological structure.
Nicolai Gogol’s ‘The Overcoat’ as a cultural symbol of transcendence.
Journeys (road, rail, plane) vs. domestic points (the kitchen).
Bengali cuisine as a symbol of intercultural malaise.
Crumpled paper clutched in train wreck symbolizing Gogol’s personality.
context: Symbols drawn from literature, popular culture, and architecture.
Globalization of American culture intersecting with traditions of Bengal.
Clothing (Overcoats) as a line of defence against changing identity.

questions.marker_instruction: A higher level response will: Explore the ways the writer uses symbols and motifs beyond obvious features; Use narrative concepts appropriately; Show an understanding of literary and generic context.

questions.text: Choose one of the storylines below to develop as the opening of a narrative.
questions.notes: Candidates should use a range of narrative techniques (dialogue, description, setting, imagery, voice, point of view).
questions.marker_instruction: Note: Candidates are writing the opening to a narrative, and can start at any point. They are not expected to write the full story and are not required to use all six bullet points.

questions.text: Outline the key narrative and linguistic techniques you have used in your writing for Question 3. You should write approximately 250 words.
questions.marker_instruction: Candidates will be expected to explain and analyse the narrative techniques they have used. They will not be expected to write about connections between their writing and the text studied for Section 3 but rather to write about the narrative concepts and techniques they have adopted.
